awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research: Scenarios for providing multiple ecosystem services and biodiversity in viticultural landscapes
awd_abstract_narration:
Innovative research on the complex interaction of socio-economic and global environmental trends of biodiversity and ecosystem services is needed to help develop more informative scenarios for addressing environmental and human development challenges. To overcome these challenges coupled natural-human systems approaches and analyses are needed. These provide improved scenarios of biodiversity and ecosystem services that couple the outputs of direct and indirect drivers, such as land use, invasive species, overexploitation, biodiversity, environmental change, and pollution. The resulting models provide a methodological state-of-the art that results in more accurate quantitative assessments, better land use, and more effective ecosystem services. This research project involves a coalition of investigators dedicated to advancing sustainable ecosystem services and maintaining essential biodiversity in agricultural landscapes with a focus on issues in vinicultural systems. Drivers such as soil fertility, pest regulation, biodiversity conservation, and crop production as a function of climate change that influence land use, economics, and policy decisions at the local, landscape, and regional level will be examined. The interdisciplinary research team, which includes members from the US academic sector, will develop and test predictive models that examine and integrate different land use and biodiversity scenarios across spatial scales for future farm management in viticultural regions across Europe.  Members of the team have extensive and well-documented collaborations with key stakeholders in the targeted regions including wine growers, non-governmental organizations, regional and national authorities, and extension service personnel. This research involves the iterative collection of input from stakeholders to help develop and test predictive models and to translate their results into a user-driven, decision-support tool that will provide wine-region vineyard farmers and regional authorities with better information and approaches on how to manage vinyards more sustainably and economically. Broader impacts of the work include international collaboration between the US, Austria, Germany, France, Spain, Romania, and The Netherlands. This large international collaboration will help build bridges collaboration and cooperation between countries and communities; engage stakeholders, ranging from local communities to national environmental protection agencies, in the process; and develop a far-reaching and rich, publicly accessible data resource that will be available to natural and social scientists across countries and disciplines.  In addition to its scientific impact, this project has societal impacts in terms of the economies of an important cash crop which will likely also impacts on US winegrowing regions. Additional impacts include the integration of research and education and the training of a postdoctoral scholar.

This award supports U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a coalition of 26 funding agencies from 23 countries through the Belmont Forum call for proposals on "Scenarios of Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services". The call was a multilateral initiative designed to support research projects that contribute to the development of scenarios, models, and decision-support tools for understanding and solving critical issues facing our planet. The goal of the competition was to improve and apply participatory scenario methods to enhance research relevance and its acceptance and to address gaps in methods for modelling impact drivers and policy interventions. It was also to develop and communicate levels of uncertainty associated with the models, to improve data accessibility and fill gaps in knowledge. Funds support U.S. participants in the larger international consortium are dedicated to synthesizing pest-control data using government-sponsored databases from Spain, France, Germany, Austria, The Netherlands, and Romania. The data will be used to develop statistical models that predict variation in pest and predator abundances across European vineyards. These models will be validated against independent field measurements, collected by European colleagues, of arthropod biodiversity, pest control, and economic performance along gradients of landscape complexity and management options across five case-study regions.  Results of the study will advance understanding of the consequences of various ecosystem services that try to address pressing challenges such as climate change, decline in worldwide biodiversity, invasive species, and unsustainable land use. Essential information from those intimately involved in vinicultural processes and land management will be collected via local focus groups which will generate stakeholder-driven scenarios. These case studies will be used to drive models that will be created and used to examine the most effective way of providing sustainable use. The validated models will be used to explore the biodiversity, ecosystem service, and crop production consequences of alternative land-use decisions under a range of social, economic and ecological restrictions.  Collaborators from other countries are funded through their associated national funding organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A key challenge is maintaining high levels of food production while minimizing unintended negative impacts on rural communities and the environment. One means to achieve this balance is adjusting farming practices to substitute nature processes such as biological pest control, nutrient cycling, and water filtration for chemical pesticides and fertilizers. However, our understanding of how farming practices affect the benefits that nature can provide— and any associated tradeoffs— remains limited. The SECBIVIT project combined field data collection, farmer interviews, analyses of ‘big data,’ and modeling to explore alternative management scenarios in vineyards across Europe. The U.S. team was specifically tasked with understanding how insect pest outbreaks and insecticide use in European vineyards and olive orchards vary between simple landscapes with vast monocultures and complex landscapes with multiple crop types and patches of natural habitat. Prior investigations into the effect of surrounding landscapes on insect pests have been inconclusive, with pests sometimes responding positively, sometimes negatively, or sometimes not at all to habitat patches around farm fields. Part of the problem is that insect pest populations are notoriously variability and most studies have not been conducted across enough farms and for enough years to tease apart landscape effects from the natural variability of pest population dynamics. In fact, many farmers’ decisions regarding pest management (e.g., insecticide applications) are heavily influenced by their strong risk-aversion to this variability: farmers will often apply excessive amounts of insecticides to avoid catastrophic pest outbreaks that can result in total crop failure. Given the paucity of long term and broad extent pest data, it thus remains unclear how conservation activities on the farm or in the surrounding landscape affect pest outbreaks (i.e., the stability of pest suppression over time).

 

The U.S. team unmasked landscape effects on pest outbreaks, stability, and insecticide use for the first time, leveraging a unique database from the government of Spain that contains more than 14 years of observations of insect pests and pesticide use across thousands of vineyards and olive groves in Southern Spain. The team found that outbreaks of one of the primary insect pests of wine grapes- the European Grapevine Moth (Lobesia botrana)- were much more likely in simple landscapes dominated by vineyards than in complex landscapes dominated by shrubland. Specifically, the likelihood that L. botrana infestations exceeded economic thresholds for spraying insecticides rose four-fold (2.5% to 10%) in landscapes without nearby vineyards vs. 90% vineyard cover. As a result, insecticide spray frequencies nearly doubled on farms surrounded by 90% vineyard cover compared to farms without vineyards nearby. The team also found that understanding pest variability is key to effectively managing olive orchards and vineyards, as more variable pest populations are more likely to downgrade crop quality and induce catastrophic damages. For example, the likelihood that one of the most damaging pests of olive orchards- the Olive Fly (Prays oleae)- would consume >20% of olive crops doubled when comparing the most versus the least variable populations. Importantly, the factors that affected pest abundances versus variability often differed, meaning pest variability must be uniquely managed. Nonetheless, the team again found that cultivating vast olive orchard monocultures increased both olive pest densities and variability, raising the likelihood that farmers would experience catastrophic crop damages.

 

The implications of the U.S. team’s findings are relevant to multiple stakeholders. For olive and wine-grape farmers, the results indicate that planting multiple crop types and maintaining habitat patches nearby may decrease the likelihood of catastrophic pest outbreaks that provoke major yield losses. For conservationists, the findings suggest that habitat conservation could simultaneously enhance crop production and biodiversity conservation goals. For government regulators and the public, the work indicates that conservation actions around farms can increase human and environmental health by mitigating pesticide use. Finally, and of equal importance, the studies highlighted the importance of large datasets for understanding the drivers and dynamics underlying pest populations, as even the strong trends identified in this study would not have been detectable in typical datasets.

 

Given the implications of these studies, disseminating project results were a major priority. The US team’s activities fell within four broad areas. First, to share findings with academic audiences, the team published multiple papers and presented at conferences and seminar series. Second, the team delivered oral presentations and participated in workshops attended by diverse audiences, including industry officials, regulators, practitioners, academics, and policy makers. Third, the team wrote press releases associated with each publication and then promoted them on social media. As a result, project results were featured in US and European online, print, and radio news media. Finally, U.S. team developed outreach materials; for example, publishing an outreach paper in a a Portuguese agricultural outreach journal and collaborating on educational videos about the team’s work.
